awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Testing and development of a time projection chamber to study neutron stars
awd_abstract_narration:
A current problem in nuclear physics is determining the nuclear equation of state. In particular, part of that equation is the symmetry energy term, which is important for the understanding of everything from the physics of nuclei to neutron stars. Neutron stars are extremely dense: a teaspoon of neutron star matter would weigh about 2 billion tons on earth. The only way that we can simulate such dense systems in the laboratory is by colliding nuclei with many neutrons together. A new magnet chamber has been created at the RI Beam factory at RIKEN in Japan which is ideally suited for studying the symmetry energy. A new Time Projection Chamber (TPC) has been created specifically for this magnet chamber, and must be tested inside the chamber before experiments can be run. The TPC takes a snapshot of what happens during each collision, revealing what types of particles are created and how many, allowing us to study the forces in dense neutron systems. This research will be conducted under the sponsorship of Dr. Hiroyoshi Sakurai at RIKEN.

The SAMURAI spectrometer is a high resolution spectrometer which, in conjunction with the newly developed SPiRIT TPC, will allow analysis of pion production ratios. Pion production ratios have been suggested as a probe of symmetry energy, and the SAMURAI setup will give the resolution to test the symmetry energy with this probe with a high angular acceptance. The beams available at the RI Beam factory will allow to constrain the symmetry energy to twice saturation density. Since the setup is new, it must be tested before it is used with actual beam time. In this study, safe and efficient procedures for setup and installation of the TPC in the spectrometer will be prepared and tested, and the readout electronics and gas system will be checked to ensure the functionality of the detector. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most important principles of physics is that the laws of physics will be the same no matter where in the universe they are observed. The laws of physics are the same on the Earth and on the Moon, and this allows us to make important predictions about environments that we cannot directly observe. One important example is neutron stars: a teaspoon of neutron matter would weigh about two billion tons on Earth. We do not have such dense materials on Earth, and it is hard to make observations of stars which are quite small in radius, but we can still study these systems by making short-lived high-density systems with heavy-ion collisions. The mass to radius relationship of neutron stars is related to the symmetry energy, which is a description of the difference of energies in a nucleus which has an equal number of protons and neutrons compared to a nucleus which has an unequal number of protons and neutrons. The SPiRIT Time Projection Chamber (TPC) has been designed and constructed by an international collaboration effort for use in the SAMURAI spectrometer in RIKEN to study the symmetry energy by measuring pion production ratios in heavy-ion collisions.

This project was planned for the following goals: test the data acquisition electronics using cosmic rays, test the cooling of these electronics, and test the procedure of installing the TPC into the magnet chamber which it will be used in. If it were possible to improve any of the procedures for these tasks, it was also desired to make the necessary improvements or modifications.

The data acquisition was extensively tested with all available electronics, and some parts were redesigned to improve performance reliability, as well as cost effectiveness. Data from cosmic rays was taken using the electronics, which demonstrated the effectiveness of the data acquisition system. The electronics were not able to be tested under a magnetic field during the project due to magnetic parts needing to be replaced, but the correct parts were ordered for a later test. The redesigned electronics setup was also tested to ensure that the spatial dimensions would be correct, and they were. The cooling system was redesigned from a water-cooled system to an air-cooled system. This option was safer, as well as simpler to implement. Installation of the TPC into the magnet chamber was tested, and it was inserted and removed safely multiple times to ensure the procedure was safe and effective. In order to maintain a safety margin, some screws were modified to have a lower profile. The completion of this project has provided crucial procedures and designs for the use of the SPiRIT TPC in the SAMURAI magnet chamber.
